text: language notes topic 8 filler words
interjections and automata pia part 1
there are similar experiences we all
have and I believe every one of us feels
the same emotions we just use different
words and sounds to express these
feelings that's mostly what this lesson
is about let's talk about filler words
interjections and onomatopoeia
filler words are words that we use to
help fill the silence when we don't know
what to say next filler words can be
actual words for example like you know
so but be careful don't make the mistake
of thinking that a lot of use of filler
words will help you sound more like a
native speaker I remember while I was
studying Japanese for a very brief time
I thought it was fun to say filler words
I still remember some it though unknown
but too many filler words in anyone's
speech could be a problem why let me
give you an example listen first
statement my name is Jennifer I'm a
teacher I'm here to help you second
statement my name is Jennifer and you
know I'm a teacher so like I'm here to
help you
which statement sounded smoother more
convincing the first one the second with
lots of filler words sounded uncertain
not very confident but here's one filler
word that could work well it's not so
bad to use this one hmm hmm we use this
sound when we're thinking so filler
words can be actual words or sounds here
are some more common ones
um so like what should we talk about
next
interjections are short words or phrases
that we use to express strong emotions
now I sometimes feel there's an overlap
between filler words and interjections
here's an example okay so this way ah
sounds like a filler word said this way
ah is an interjection what am i
expressing ah kind of surprised maybe
some kind of discovery right so let's
try this I'll say an interjection and
you try to identify what I'm expressing
okay
aha
kind of like surprise a good surprise
maybe discovery ha same thing so AHA or
Toa
express a similar emotion but ha a
little more emphatically could be
because I'm feeling victorious
maybe I won I'm saying hoots so there ha
ok also that wasn't very polite so be
careful with some of these interjections
ok a few more huh meaning what what was
that what did you say
I'll take that same interjection now and
use it differently you liked it huh I'm
asking for agreement uh-huh yes uh-huh
no uh-oh there's some kind of bad
surprise or something bad happened I'm
surprised and disappointed worried even
uh-oh okay
Oh
I'm expressing maybe sympathy something
bad happened something sad
compared to Oh something is sweet or
cute boo a sound we used to surprise
someone compared boo - boo hoo that's
the sound of crying boo hoo BRR I'm cold
duh duh this is very rude duh refers to
someone stupidity something is stupid in
my opinion I'm saying hello duh
it could be very rude so be careful with
this alright how about another one
ouch I hurt myself okay Oh Oh is very
versatile it could be oh I'm worried I'm
concerned Oh a knowing feeling oh really
I can't believe that surprise yikes
something bad happened and I'm very
surprised about this yikes
you can combine them ouch yikes
hey is another very versatile
interjection I could say hey like a
greeting or I could say hey meaning be
careful why did you do that
where hey like this is really good hey
hey this is really really good and I'm
so happy to see the situation okay so
hey is very versatile just like Oh all
depends on the intonation the melody of
your voice let's do more positive
interjections you heard hey what about
yay like that's good good for you I'm
happy or
happy for us yay is similar to hooray
hooray yay could be used sarcastically -
yay hooray Bravo well done Wow
like I'm really impressed again could be
used sarcastically Wow Wow
be careful with introductions so much is
conveyed with your intonation you can be
genuine you could be rude so be careful
here are a few interjections I hope you
don't have to use too often yak right
something is distasteful either
literally or figuratively similarly we
have ooh that's disgusting that's gross
ugh again there's something that I don't
like I'm reacting negatively I don't
want to hear this see this or experience
this all three negative here are a
number of interjections with a negative
feeling attached to them okay here's the
first argh I'm experiencing frustration
okay if I make a mistake I might say
dang or darn these are not really bad
words but they're certainly not
preferable in polite company
there are worse but they're not great in
polite company okay similarly we have
rats shoot okay how about these oops
you might also hear whoops
kids say oopsies
all of these interjections are spoken
when we make some kind of mistake oops
whoops oopsies
jeez can be spelled different ways jeez
jeez like I can't believe that oh my
gosh gosh is also could be said by
children but it's still not the best of
interjections gosh could be used to
express sympathy gosh really I'm so
sorry that could also be surprised in a
negative way gosh the list of
interjections in English is long the
last three I'll share all begin with the
letter W how about this one whoa whoa
there are a lot of interjections I say
whoa to express surprise at the volume
or something there's too much of
something or a lot of something whoa
compared to wow I'm just generally
impressed and now that I'm at the end of
my list of interjections I'll say whew
I'm relieved this is the end of part 1
